coredata.dc:title: Rheological behaviour of Magnetorheological polishing fluid for Si polishing
coredata.prism:issueName: 5th International Conference of Materials Processing and Characterization (ICMPC 2016)
coredata.dc:creator: Saraswathamma, K.
Jha, Sunil
Venkateswara Rao, P.
coredata.dc:description: The finishing mechanism of the magnetorheological finishing (MRF) process primarily depends on the Magnetorheological polishing (MRP) fluid, which acts as a tool in finishing the component surfaces. MRP fluid imparts strength to the polishing spot under the applied magnetizing currents/magnetic field strength. Behaviour of this fluid mainly influenced by the size and shape of its constituents, volume concentration, particle size distribution, and applied magnetic field strength. A detailed study was undertaken on the role of carbonyl iron particle (CIP) and abrasive size on the rheological behaviour of the MRP fluid under various magnetic flux densities. Rheological characterization study was carried out using three different models such as Bingham plastic model, Herschel-Bulkley model and Casson fluid model. MRP fluid rheological properties such as yield stress and viscosity were evaluated using parallel plate magnetorheometer.

Magnetizing current
Yield stress

xocs:doc.xocs:rawtext: Available online at www.sciencedirect.com ScienceDirect Materials Today: Proceedings 4 (2017) 1478â€“1491 www.materialstoday.com/proceedings 5th International Conference of Materials Processing and Characterization (ICMPC 2016) Rheological behaviour of Magnetorheological polishing fluid for Si polishing Saraswathamma. Ka*, Sunil Jhab and Venkateswara Rao. Pb 1 Department of Mechanical Engineering, Osmania University, India 2 Department of Mechanical Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology Delhi, India Abstract The finishing mechanism of the magnetorheological finishing (MRF) process primarily depends on the Magnetorheological polishing (MRP) fluid, which acts as a tool in finishing the component surfaces. MRP fluid imparts strength to the polishing spot under the applied magnetizing currents/magnetic field strength. Behaviour of this fluid mainly influenced by the size and shape of its constituents, volume concentration, particle size distribution, and applied magnetic field strength. A detailed study was undertaken on the role of carbonyl iron particle (CIP) and abrasive size on the rheological behaviour of the MRP fluid under various magnetic flux densities. Rheological characterization study was carried out using three different models such as Bingham plastic model, Herschel-Bulkley model and Casson fluid model. MRP fluid rheological properties such as yield stress and viscosity were evaluated using parallel plate magnetorheometer. Â©2017 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved. Selection and peer-review under responsibility of Conference Committee Members of 5th International Conference of Materials Processing and Characterization (ICMPC 2016). Keywords: Parallel plate magnetorheometer, Carbonyl iron powder, cerium oxide abarsive, magnetizing current, yield stress, viscosity *Corresponding author. Tel:9032714222. E-mail address:saraswathi.ouce@gmail.com 2214-7853Â©2017 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved. Selection and peer-review under responsibility of Conference Committee Members of 5th International Conference of Materials Processing and Characterization (ICMPC 2016). Saraswathamma. K et al./ Materials Today: Proceedings 4 (2017) 1478â€“1491 1479 1. Introduction The finishing action in all magnetorheological fluid assisted finishing processes, depends primarily on bonding strength of CIP particles around the abrasive particles in magnetorheological polishing (MRP) fluid, due to crossed linked cluster nature of CIP particles [1]. MR polishing fluid properties like shear yield stress and viscosity are altered by using magnetizing current, which is produced by electromagnetic coils at the finishing zone. The essential characteristic of MR polishing fluid is that they can be rapidly and reversibly varied from the state of a Newtonian-like fluid to that of a stiff semisolid with the application of a moderate magnetic field. Due to alterations of the rheological properties of the MR polishing fluid under the variation of magnetic field, the finishing forces can better controlled in the MRF processes. Even though CIP is the main constituent for creating magnetorheological effect in MR polishing fluid, addition of abrasive particles in the MR fluid may affect the rheological properties (yield stress and viscosity) of the fluid. In the present work, rheological study of MR polishing fluid is focused to observe the effect of different particle size with non-magnetic abrasives under different magnetic strengths. Rheological properties of the MR polishing fluid at different shearing conditions play a significant role in the finishing mechanism. Several attempts have already been made by researchers for accommodating electromagnets in existing rheometer sample shearing zone. Presence of abrasive particles in MR polishing fluid would impair the surface of the commercial rheometer, which is very costly. Moreover, to comprehend the effect of rheological properties in the finishing mechanism of BEMRF, similar kinds of geometry and field distribution are required. For this reason, in conjunction with BEMRF, a parallel-plate magnetorheometer is designed and fabricated. 2. MR polishing fluid for Si polishing Magnetorheological (MR) polishing fluid is a mixture of micron sized non-colloidal iron particles and abrasives that are dispersed in an aqueous or non-aqueous carrier medium. These fluids are field controllable fluids exhibiting unique, reversible rheological properties on application and removal of the magnetic field. Considering its higher magnetic saturation and least cost, pure iron was chosen for preparation of MR polishing fluid. High purity Carbonyl Iron particles (CIP) are prepared from decomposition of pentacarbonyl iron which are also magnetically softer. Sidpara and Jain [2] conducted an experimental investigation to study the effect of chemical interactions of abrasive and carrier fluid. Their study revealed that carrier medium plays a crucial role in polishing of silicon. Type of abrasive plays a key role in finishing of brittle materials like glass and silicon. Cerium oxide is extensively used in glass polishing industry from several decades. Recent studies show that CMP also utilizing ceria slurries for polishing silicon due to its chemical properties. Cook illustrated chemical tooth of cerium oxide and its strong interaction with silicate ions which promotes the removal in silicon based materials[3]. Ceria abrasive is also utilized for finishing silicon and other related silicate glasses in the MRF process [4-8]. Glycerol is used as stabilizers in water-based MR polishing fluids. Alkalis (viz NaOH, KOH) helps to improve the stability and resistance to rust of the iron particles and also maintains the pH (strong influence on CMP of Silicon) of the MR polishing fluid [9, 10]. 1480 Saraswathamma. K et al./ Materials Today: 4 (2017) 1478â€“1491 3. Experimental setup and procedure A schematic sketch of the magnetorheometer is displayed in Fig. 1. Magnetorheometer consists of two parallel plates, an electromagnet circuit, servomotor, a torque sensor, and a data acquisition card with Labview software. In this magnetorheometer, the top plate was kept static and the bottom plate was rotated with the help of a servomotor; the MR polishing fluid is placed in between the shearing plates. Magnetic field is applied perpendicularly to these plates, so that the CI particles are aligned along the magnetic field direction.When a defined speed is applied to the lower plate, the resultant torque is measured using a torque transducer, which is attached to the top plate. The stress required to shear the fluid is measured by varying the magnetic field intensity. Electromagnet is made into two parts for easy placing and removal of the sample. A cooling coil is provided at the bottom of the core to minimize the heating of the coil. Current to the coil is supplied through variable regulated DC power supply. The top electromagnetic core and the top plate are attached to a linear slide (vertical) through a fixture, which is moved up and down by a stepper motor to place and remove the testing sample. Experiments were conducted to evaluate the rheological properties of MR polishing fluid with different particle sizes of CIP and cerium oxide under different magnetic field strength conditions. Table 1 (ii) summarizes six different MR polishing fluids prepared from different combinations of three grades of carbonyl iron powder (Table 2) and two different sizes of cerium oxide abrasives (Table 3). D10, D50, D90 in Table 2 denote the diameter of 10%, 50%, and 90% of particles respectively. CIP volume concentration, abrasive volume concentration, and glycerol volume concentration are kept constant at 30%, 6%, and 3% respectively. The rest is deionized (DI) water, which makes 100% vol of MR polishing fluid. MR polishing fluid of carbonyl iron powder, abrasives and glycerol in DI water was prepared by continuously mixing with multiple blade stirrer for one hour in order to get uniform dispersion of carbonyl iron and abrasive particles in water. Toque is measured at varying angular velocities; further these are converted in to strain rate and shear stresses using the constitutive relation. Angular velocities were varied from 0.5 rps to 5 rps at a step of 0.5 rps and magnetic field strength was varied by varying the current from 1 A to 4 A. All measurements are done at 1 mm gap of plates and at room temperature. Table 4 shows the plan of experiments.The shear rates and shear stresses were converted using the following constitutive relation [11]. K et al./ Materials Today: Proceedings 4 (2017) 1478â€“1491 1483 4. Characterization models for MR polishing fluid Magnetorheology is the branch of rheology that deals with the flow and deformation of materials under an applied magnetic field [13]. The rheological properties of MR fluids depend on particle size and shape, density, particle size distribution, concentration of the constituents, properties of carrier fluids, surfactants, anticorrosion additives, temperature, applied magnetic field and magnetic properties of the CI particles. However, the relationships between large numbers of parameters are very complex and there is no optimized methodology as yet, to understand the effect on the finishing process. In the absence of the magnetic field, the MR fluids appear like liquid paints and show the apparent viscosity 0.1 to 1 Pas-1 at lower shear rates. Upon application of magnetic field, the iron particles acquire dipole moment and align in the magnetic field direction and forms a chain like structure. Formation of these chains of particles restricts the flow of material, which increases the yield stress of the material. The yield stress and shear viscosity of the material increases with increase in applied magnetic field. To break this structure and ensure flow of the material, mechanical energy (shear stress) is applied in the direction perpendicular to the chain formation. Experimental evidence has confirmed that in the presence of magnetic field, MR fluids exhibited both a pre-yield regime characterized by an elastic response and post yield regime characterized by viscous response [14]. To characterize the rheological properties (field-induced yield stress and viscosity), three constitutive models are generally used viz Bingham Plastic model, Herschel-Bulkley model, and Casson Fluid model. In Bingham Plastic model (Fig. 2), the material flow behaviour is assumed as elastic solid up to critical shear stress(yield stress), beyond which the material starts flowing and behaves like Newtonian fluid. The constitutive equation for this model is as follows ð�œ� = ð�œ�0 + ð�œ‚ð�›¾ Ì‡ ð�‘“ð�‘œð�‘Ÿ ð�œ� > ð�œ�0 (4) ð�œ� = 0 ð�‘“ð�‘œð�‘Ÿ ð�œ� â‰¤ ð�œ�0 where Ï„ is the shear stress of the fluid, ð�œ�0 is the field induced dynamic yield stress, Î· is the plastic viscosity of fluid, and ?Ì‡? is shear rate (1/s). The dynamic yield stress is the intercept of extrapolation of the shear stress vs. shear rate curve to zero strain rate. On the other hand, in Herschel- Bulkley model (Fig. 2), behaviour of flow of material is described as non-Newtonian after the critical shear stress (yield stress) and below this stage the material behaves as elastic solid, which is same as in case of Bingham Model. This model is expressed as ð�œ� = ð�œ�0 + ÎšÎ³Ì‡ð�‘› ð�‘“ð�‘œð�‘Ÿ ð�œ� > ð�œ�0 (5) ð�œ� = 0 ð�‘“ð�‘œð�‘Ÿ ð�œ� â‰¤ ð�œ�0 where K is consistency parameter and n is flow behaviour index. The value of flow index in this model indicates the fluid behaviour. In case of shear thinning, the flow index is less than 1 and for shear thickening the value of the flow index is greater than 1. If the value of flow index is equal to 1, then the behaviour of the model is same as Bingham Plastic model. 1484 Saraswathamma. K et al./ Materials Today: 4 (2017) 1478â€“1491 Cassonâ€™s equation (Fig. 2) is time independent shear flow, which relates nonlinear shear rate and shear stress. A Casson fluid is defined as a shear thinning fluid which is assumed to have an infinite viscosity at zero rate of shear, a yield stress below which no flow occurs and a zero viscosity at an infinite rate of shear [15]. Cassonâ€™s flow model is given as âˆšð�œ� = ï¿½ð�œ�0 + ï¿½ð�œ‚âˆž ?Ì‡? ð�‘“ð�‘œð�‘Ÿ ð�œ� > ð�œ�0 (6) whereð�œ�0 is yield stress, ð�œ‚âˆž is viscosity of the material at higher shear rates. Fig. 2. Constitutive models for MR polishing fluid flow characterisation [1] Results and discussion The three constitutive models such as Bingham plastic, Herschel-Bulkley, and Casson fluid are used to characterize rheological behavior of MR polishing fluid. The measured rheological data were fitted for these three models to evaluate the respective constants from their equations. From the experimental data obtained from parallel plate magnetorheometer, flow curves in terms of shear stress vs shear rate for all the fluids at four magnetizing currents were plotted. Flow curves for MR polishing fluid CS grade CIP with ceria 2.4Âµm abrasive at four different magnetizing currents are shown in Fig.3 (a-d). Saraswathamma. K et al./ Materials Today: Proceedings 4 (2017) 1478â€“1491 1485 Fig.3 Flow curves for MRPF CS_Rhodite at (a) 1A (b) 2A (C) 3A (d) 4A current 1486 Saraswathamma. K et al./ Materials Today: 4 (2017) 1478â€“1491 The rheological parameters obtained for Bingham plastic, Herschel-Bulkley, and Casson fluid curves are given in Tables 5 and 6 respectively. In these three models, it is assumed that pre-yield behaviour is rigid and the fluid flows if and only if the local shear stress is greater than the yield stress. Bingham plastic model is a two parameter model (yield stress and viscosity) and the fluid behaviour in pre yield is represented as rigid and post yield as linear. For Herschel-Bulkley model pre yield behaviour is rigid same as the Bingham plastic model, and post yield behaviour is nonlinear. This model employ three parameters such as yield stress (ð�œ�0 ), consistency (K) and flow index (n). Flow index of the curve indicates whether the fluid is shear thickening or shear thinning. Flow index n>1 indicates a shear thickening fluid and n<1 indicates a shear thinning fluid. Casson fluid model is a two parameter model (yield stress and Cassonâ€™s viscosity) and represents continuous shear thinning fluid behaviour. Table 5. K et al./ Materials Today: Proceedings 4 (2017) 1478â€“1491 1487 The curvature in Herschel-Bulkley and Casson fluid model (Fig.3) indicates that shear thinning of the fluid and it varies from fluid to fluid based on the constituents and magnetic flux density. The flow index of all MR polishing fluids (ignoring the fluid made with CIP_OS and Rhodite grade of abrasive and CIP_CS and Unicer grade of abrasive) as per Table 5&6 lies between 0.15 -0.98, which is evident for shear thinning behavior of MR polishing fluids. Herschel-Bulkley model fits the data points well compared to the other models. But most of the cases consistency factor is either very high value or negative. These consistency values have no practical meaning. Bingham plastic model was simplistic model and most of the researchers had used it represent the behaviour of MR fluid (without addition of non-magnetic particles). But Ginder [16] observed the shear thinning behaviour of MR fluid (i.e the fluid apparent viscosity decreases with increase in shear rate). According to the available literature, Bingham plastic model was not realistic model to represent the behaviour of the MR polishing fluid. Jha and Jain [15] and Sidpara et al. [17] reported from their rheological characterization study that, Herschel-Bulkley model fitted well with MR polishing fluid curve and the fluid is exhibiting shear thinning behaviour. On the other hand, Casson fluid model represents a continuous shear thinning behaviour of the fluid with decrease in viscosity from infinite at zero shear rates to zero at infinite shear rate. Hence, for the present study, Casson fluid model was used to characterize the MR polishing fluid properties (yield stress and viscosity). Table 6. K et al./ Materials Today: 4 (2017) 1478â€“1491 5.1Yield stress Iron particles are the main constituent in the preparation of MR polishing fluid. When no magnetic field applied, the fluid shows Newtonian fluid like behaviour and no external pressure is required to make the fluid flow. Once magnetic field is applied, the iron particles align in the direction of magnetic field. Thus, Iron particles and magnetic flux density are the two dependent parameters to achieve magnetorheological effect. Increase in yield stress with increase in magnetic flux density for MR fluid was widely reported in the literature. The presence of abrasive particles (nonmagnetic) in the MR polishing fluid may affect the chain strength for the applied magnetic flux density. It is observed from Fig. 4 and Fig .5 that yield stress increases with increase in magnetizing current for all combinations of MR polishing fluid. When magnetic field is applied to the MR polishing fluid, the carbonyl Iron particles which are in the fluid acquire dipole moment and aggregate intocolumnar structure along the field direction. Energy is required to deform or rupture these chains, the micro-structural transition is responsible for onset of a large controllable yield stress [18]. The strength of the columnar structure depends greatly on the applied magnetic field flux density and which in turn depends on the diameter of the iron particle. Force on a small ferromagnetic particle of mass â€˜mâ€™[19] is given as ð��¹ð�‘š = ð�‘šð�œ’ð�‘ ð�œ‡0 Î’âˆ‡Î’ (7) Ginder[16] also observed from experimental study that the yield stress is a power-law function of the flux densityð�œ�ð�‘¦~ð��µ3 2â�„ . Induced dipole moment for formation of structure is given as [20] ð�‘šð�‘‘ = Ï€ð�‘‘32 ï¿½ ð�œ‡ð�‘�âˆ’ð�œ‡ð�‘“ð�œ‡ð�‘�+2ð�œ‡ð�‘“ï¿½ Î—ð�œŠ (8) whered is particle diameter, ð�œ‡ð�‘� is the particle permeability and ð�œ‡ð�‘“ is the fluid permeability. Gorodkin et al [21] reported in their study that specific magnetic susceptibility, ð�œ’ð�‘ of iron particles is a linear function of median particle size. Because of high susceptibility, interaction forces increases. Therefore, more energy is required to rupture the chains of MR fluid. Even in case of MRF finishing, researchers have reported that if the applied magnetic field and CIP particle size increase, the material removal rate increases [6]. Fig. 4 Variation of yield stress with CIP grades and Rhodite abrasive Fig. 5 Variation of yield stress with CIP grades and Unicer abrasive 10 14 18 22 26 30 0 0.5 1 1.5 2 2.5 3 3.5 4 4.5 Y ie ld st re ss (k Pa ) Magnetizing current (A) CS_R OS_R HS_R 0 10 20 30 40 0 0.5 1 1.5 2 2.5 3 3.5 4 4.5 Y ie ld st re ss (k Pa ) Magnetizing current (A) CS_U OS_U HS_U Saraswathamma. K et al./ Materials Today: Proceedings 4 (2017) 1478â€“1491 1489 5.2 Viscosity Field induced yield shear stress governs the flow commencement, while shear viscosity represents the flow behaviour once the flow starts. The breakage of chain structure and reformation of clusters during flow are represented by viscosity. For MR fluid, nonlinear relation between shear stress and shear rate indicating shearthinning behaviour is observed. Due to this behaviour, viscosity is a function of shear rate and it is not constant. âˆšð�œ� = ï¿½ð�œ�0 + ï¿½ð�œ‚âˆž ?Ì‡? ð�‘“ð�‘œð�‘Ÿ ð�œ� > ð�œ�0 (9) In MR Polishing fluid, non-magnetic abrasives trapped in the chain structure affect the flow behaviour of the fluid. Due to this complex nature, it is difficult to arrive at some conclusion over the behaviour of the fluid. Increase in viscosity of MR Polishing fluid prepared with CIP-CS and CIP-HS was observed with increase in magnetic field current (Fig. 6). CIP-OS is coated with SiO2, and this can be the reason for the fluid prepared with CIP-OS to show more shear thinning nature at different shear rates. It was observed that even in the absence of magnetic field, the apparent viscosity of CIP-OS fluid is less compared to the other fluids prepared with CIP-CS and CIP-HS. But the fluid prepared with CIP-HS shows more viscosity than the other two. The size of CIP-HS and ceria abrasives are almost same and the number of CIP particles is more around the abrasive particle, which may shows some resistance to flow. But amount of change of CIP-HS viscosity is less compared to that of CIP-CS with variation of magnetizing current. This may be due to the fact that CIP-CS is bigger in size and is more susceptible. The variation of viscosity with the fluid prepared with CIP_CS and Unicer grade of abrasive does not seem to follow any concluding trend (Fig.7). This may be due to the size variation is bigger in between the CIP_CS and Unicer grade of abrasive. Due to complexity of MR polishing fluid nature, a more detailed study on this is required to understand the role of particle size on viscosity. K et al./ Materials Today: 4 (2017) 1478â€“1491 6 Conclusions â€¢ Based on the experimental study, it was observed â€¢ The rheological properties (Yield stress and viscosity) are function of carbonyl iron particle and abrasive size under magnetic flux density which increases with increase in particle size and magnetic flux density. â€¢ More shear thinning behaviour was observed in case of SiO2 coated CIP with and without external magnetic flux density. â€¢ The variation of viscosity with the fluid prepared with CIP_CS and Unicer grade of abrasive does not seem to follow any concluding trend. head.ce:title: Rheological behaviour of Magnetorheological polishing fluid for Si polishing

ce:affiliation.ce:label: a
ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: Department of Mechanical Engineering, Osmania University, India

ce:affiliation.ce:label: b
ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: Department of Mechanical Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology Delhi, India

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: The finishing mechanism of the magnetorheological finishing (MRF) process primarily depends on the Magnetorheological polishing (MRP) fluid, which acts as a tool in finishing the component surfaces. MRP fluid imparts strength to the polishing spot under the applied magnetizing currents/magnetic field strength. Behaviour of this fluid mainly influenced by the size and shape of its constituents, volume concentration, particle size distribution, and applied magnetic field strength. A detailed study was undertaken on the role of carbonyl iron particle (CIP) and abrasive size on the rheological behaviour of the MRP fluid under various magnetic flux densities. Rheological characterization study was carried out using three different models such as Bingham plastic model, Herschel-Bulkley model and Casson fluid model. MRP fluid rheological properties such as yield stress and viscosity were evaluated using parallel plate magnetorheometer.
